content:
To get information about the demographics of your local community, including the top languages spoken and the percentage of non-English speakers, you can use the following resources:

1. **American Community Survey (ACS) Website**: The ACS is a survey conducted by the US Census Bureau that provides detailed data on demographics, including language spoken at home, for various geographic areas.
	* Visit the ACS website ([www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs](http://www.census.gov/programs-surveys/acs)) and click on "Data" > "Get Data" > "Advanced Search".
	* Enter your city, county, or zip code in the "Geography" section.
	* Select "Language Spoken at Home" under "Topics" and choose the specific data you're interested in (e.g., "Language Spoken at Home by Ability to Speak English" or "Language Spoken at Home by Age").
	* Click "Get Data" to access the data tables.
2. **US Census Bureau's QuickFacts**: QuickFacts provides demographic data, including language spoken at home, for cities, counties, and states.
	* Visit the QuickFacts website ([quickfacts.census.gov](http://quickfacts.census.gov)) and enter your city, county, or state in the search bar.
	* Click on the "Language" tab to access data on language spoken at home.
3. **Data.census.gov**: This platform provides access to a wide range of demographic data, including language spoken at home.
	* Visit [data.census.gov](http://data.census.gov) and click on "Explore Data" > "Demographics" > "Language".
	* Enter your city, county, or zip code in the "Geography" section.
	* Select the specific data you're interested in (e.g., "Language Spoken at Home" or "Language Spoken at Home by Ability to Speak English").
	* Click "Get Data" to access the data tables.
4. **NeighborhoodScout**: This is a commercial tool that provides demographic data, including language spoken, for neighborhoods and zip codes.
	* Visit [www.neighborhoodscout.com](http://www.neighborhoodscout.com) and enter your zip code or neighborhood name.
	* Click on the "Demographics" tab to access data on language spoken at home.

Some examples of data you might find include:

* Top languages spoken at home (e.g., Spanish, Chinese, Tagalog, Vietnamese, etc.)
* Percentage of non-English speakers
* Percentage of households speaking a language other than English at home
* Language proficiency (e.g., percentage of people speaking English "very well" or "not at all")

Keep in mind that the availability and granularity of data may vary depending on the resource and the specific geographic area.
